You can also read your counterpart, i.e. those composed by the PRO group participants in a previous session, to inspire more thoughts and develop arguments.

Here are some strategies you can take advantage of to organize your teamwork:
Option1: Separately compose claims and develop backings as far as you can, then upon certain amount of time, exchange the ones you’ve worked on and discuss upon them, add on them or revise them etc.
Option2: Discuss first with who to take on which role(s)/sub-task(s) and initiate discussion when needed.
Option3: Reach consensus on the outline/schema of your arguments as a whole and then develop them together.
Option4: Be as creative as you can, and strategize your unique adventure with Critical Thinker!
So guys I am confused about how to catechize the situation.  Many of my arguments have been stated previously
You just need to compose roughly correspondent argument, it could just be on the same level or perspective
or similar one
ok

What the CON group did is to construct opposing opinions on the right.

okay

Just a hint, I think your opposing side are arguing from the consequences, feasibility, how practical it would be. But you can say some positive impact or opportunities that make the right viable.
k

Oh ok I get it

we are against the right to be forgotten right?

yea. what do you have in mind?

i agree with that

i am thinking about public safety issue
if the criminal has committed felony, the public has the right to know
what do you think?

left?

10 minutes

Now it is time to consider both sides and develop three small paragraphs that synthesize what you and the previous CON group have developed.
Whats up
Hey
So what argument can we make for this?
So we are arguing for the Pro side of the Righ to be forgotten, right?
yes
Ok
So I was thinking we could say something like the laws allow for mistakes to be taken away
Well, I can see an analogy where the internet is like a library. You cant expect libraries to not house books that you dont like
"laws allow for mistakes to be taken away" I feel like this is too general
I agree
Maybe make an argument for if there is only a charge and no conviction/ inaccurate or fraudulent charges
That those are unreasonable to keep up
Thats true.  Thats a good one.  I forget which document that was in but i remember reading it
Or use an analogy that likens the internet to a giant billboard. You can put someting up but I cant take it down. In real life, i could take it down. So why not online?
Exactly.  You should be able to make mistakes without it ruining your life
Some people might argue that this is only beneficial to the powerful (politicians hiding things), but a counter-agruement is  that they are still people. They have the same rights as you and I
^ That is kinda off topic
its okay.  I think thats a good argument to start.  We can come up with other things as we go along
Ok. I definately think we should keep the idea of inaccurate charges as one of our main points
How long do we have for this?
I agree too.  We need to also say something about how the websites should be liable if the photos are not removed
and Im not sure
You have 17 minutes until 10:30PM.
ok
Okay.  So our argument begins at 10:30?
"websites should be liable if the photos are not removed"
yes
is that a point or restating the right...?
No it ends at 10:35PM, I will make it less constraint since I was interrupting your process just now by restarting the server
Sorry about that
I mean its good, but not exatly supporting it
restating the right but we should make a point on it
ok
I agree
Do each of us make 2 points, or 2 for us togehter?
Im not sure Like we could say something like "A websites responsibility is to make sure the users are happy.  This right allows for all of them to have a good experience with posting on the internet"
each of you make/come up with 2 points, and communicate them to each other
Okay.  So we have two points so far.  What else?
ok that sounds like a good point, mentioning the userbase and all
However, since it is a collaborative work, you can always help your partner to come up with or refine the other person's argument.
And then we type them into the boxes, yes?
Okay thank you

Okay.  How would we support that from the text?
Like if oyu google a name, a mugshot will come up unless the website is payed to take it down
umm
hang on
maybe just quote the french law

"French law, which recognizes le droit à l’oubli—or the “right of oblivion”—a right that allows a convicted criminal who has served his time and been rehabilitated to object to the publication of the facts of his conviction and incarceration"
^ from first pdf

Welcome to Critical Thinker. This is where you can chat, but start to learn how to use the system by clicking the grey question button at the top of the page.

To extend on the relevant part, if someone was at one time in a profession/group/etc. they would not like to share with the general public, then i believe they should have the right for that information associated with their name to be taken down

I think a con would be that it could interfere with education and school work.  If articles are taken down about the past, how are we supposed to learn about it or possibly do research projects on it
i think that a great idea!
Also referencing becomes hard without documentation.

It could also put people in danger.  You may be working with an ex-convict and not know it.  I don't know if this law would stop you from having to write that on a job application? but you still would not be able to find basic information about people.  Say I wanted a babysitter, I would like to know all information about that person before they watch my child, and know that no information is missing.
Any other ideas?
